editionStmt.funder: Conversion of the printed catalogue to TEI funded by the Warden and Fellows of Merton College .

note.locus: (fols. i–ii, 1) blank. On fol. 1v is a table of contents and a list of the tituli to art. 1, in two different hands, s. xv ex.

msItem.author: JOHN DUNS SCOTUS
msItem.title: Quodlibeta
msItem.incipit: Cuncte res difficiles ait Salomon. Eccles. primo et cur intelligat eas esse difficiles subdit

msItem.author: JOHN DUNS SCOTUS
msItem.title: De Primo Principio
msItem.incipit: Primum uerum principium mihi ea credere sapere
msItem.explicit: ergo hoc non est ergo neuter est opt’ exª
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit primus tractatus I. Scoti de primo principio
msItem.note: Ed. A. B. Wolter (Chicago, ILL, 1983), pp. 3–151, here with a short addition to the printed text ‘Opt’ contingentis uult omne alio a se saltem causale ...’. Glorieux, Théol. 344h.

msItem.author: Ps.-JOHN DUNS SCOTUS
msItem.title: De Cognitione Dei
msItem.incipit: Quia supprema cognicio nobis potentiali natura de Deo habetur
msItem.explicit: sunt ueritates scibiles nisi tamen funte
msItem.note: This does not seem to be the same text of which a fragment is pr. DSO (Wadding), 3. 431–40; Glorieux, Théol, 344ad. Tanner, pp. 238–9 n. a, reports this copy, but gives the incipit ‘Quia summa nobis cognitio est’, as Bale, Scriptores i. 363. Another copy with the present incipit is in Assisi, Bibl. comm. 172, fols. 117v-20v.

msItem.author: JOHN DUNS SCOTUS
msItem.title: Collationes Parisienses
msItem.incipit: Vtrum sit tamen una prudencia directum respectu omnium agibilium ita quod ad dirigendum omnis actus morales in suos fines sufficiat una prudencia
msItem.explicit: alia in Filio et sic de Spiritus Sancto igitur &c
msItem.note: DSO (Wadding), 3. 345–430; Glorieux, Théol. 344u1. 19 quaestiones, 1–17 corresponding to Wadding 1, 8, 6–7, 2–4, 17–18, 9–11, 20, 36–9; then follow two pr. from this and MS 65 by Harris, Duns Scotus, II, pp. 361–70. The text varies much from the printed version.

msItem.author: JOHN DUNS SCOTUS
msItem.title: Collationes Oxonienses
msItem.rubric: Collationes Oxonienses secundum doctorem subtilem et sunt collationes 3, 5, 25
msItem.incipit: Vtrum cum simplicitate persone diuine posset scire pluralitas racionum realium in eadem ante omne actum intellectus. Probo quod non quia pluralitas rationum intellectualium substancie
msItem.note: DSO (Wadding), 3. 345–430; Glorieux, Théol. 344u2. Divided into eightquaestiones. 1–3, 5–8 are Wadding 23, 26, 19, 30, 34, 12, 32; cf. MS 65 art. 2. No. 4 is ‘Vtrum g’tus entis sit simpliciter unicus Deo et creaturis’.

supportDesc.collation: A singleton, hooked around the first quire, A4(2–3 canc.), 112(6 canc.), 212(2 canc.), 3–512, 6–178, 1812, 19–228, 238(+ 1 before 1), 248, 258(lacking 2–8, a bifolium, formerly following this quire, inserted after 1); catchwords.

layoutDesc.layout: Frame-ruled with crayon, written in 35–8 long lines.

handDesc.handNote: Small, neat secretary hands. Marginal annotation throughout in several contemporary hands; one of them may be that of the second table of contents, which is perhaps the hand of Thomas Gawge.

decoDesc.decoNote: Blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs.

binding.p: Standard Merton s. xvii, sewn on five bands; chained from the usual position.

history.provenance: At the head of fol. 1v ‘Liber domus scolarium de Mertone in Oxonia ex dono M. Thome Gaugge quondam socii eiusdem domus ad incathenandum in libraria ibidem.’ For Gawge, fellowc. 1441–8, d. 1470, see MS 43.
Inside the front board is a table of contents, s. xvii, ‘N. 7. 10 Art:’, s. xvii, canc. and replaced by ‘H. 1. 6’, in red, and the College bookplate. ‘10’ is inked on the foredge.

source.bibl: R. M. Thomson, A descriptive catalogue of the medieval manuscripts of Merton College, Oxford (Cambridge: D. S. Brewer), 2009.

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact Merton College Library.
